results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke.

In this film, the filmmaker shows life on and around the beach at Anglesea in Victoria - walking, hang gliding, surfing, motoring in the dunes and on the sand, taking in the views from the cliffs. Wallace focuses on examples of coastal wildflowers as well as animal life where he finds it.

Originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:06:46:00 hikers in the dunes.
00:11:00:00 a large snake in a tree.
00:11:25:00 hang gliding off the cliffs.
00:13:28:00 walkers on the beach.
00:15:23:00 a crab in the shallows.
00:16:04:00 surfing.
00:18:54:00 a jeep pulling a stuck ‘Holden’ station wagon car from the sand.
00:19:30:00 women looking over the view from the dunes.
00:19:54:00 a ‘jeep’ vehicle charging up a steep dune track.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 4: Part 1]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film, titled ‘Fascinating Fiji’, contains scenes of Fiji landscapes, towns and resorts. The filmmaker takes footage from a vehicle so that the scenes change with his travels. Much of the reel is taken up with scenic vistas of roadside crops, lush greenery, trees and flowers, hills in the distance and the sea.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:05:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Fascinating Fiji’, ‘A WHC Film’
00:00:38:00 drive through a plantation
00:01:05:00 buffalo
00:01:31:00 sign for the Raki Raki Hotel.
00:03:44:00 seaside township
00:04:10:00 foraging on the foreshore.
00:04:40:00 sign ‘Welcome to Nausori’ before crossing the (old) Rewa bridge by car.
00:04:56:00 ‘Nausori Municipal Market’ on the island of ‘Viti Levu’ showing various vegetable stalls and some produce boxes from New Zealand.
00:05:45:00 sign for ‘Kings Road’ showing miles to various destinations
00:06:16:00 woman paddling a slim canoe on water before small boys in a boat.
00:10:14:00 football game
00:11:10:00 one of Wallace’s travelling companions holds a tourist pose for the camera.destinations

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 26]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is situated in the Victorian Alpine Region in the summer months when the only snows are at the very top of the mountains. Wallace focuses on the roads that wind, at times dramatically, through the mountain range as well as the surrounding landscape of trees, rocks and waterways.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 titles ‘WHC Presents’, ‘The Victorian Alps’
00:00:50:00 views from the road and a small old house
00:01:06:00 sign ‘Alpine Road’ with lots of information for the traveller
00:01:25:00 sign ‘You are now entering Mount Hotham Alpine Reserve’
00:01:35:00 looking across a corner of a dirt road high up in the mountains
00:02:22:00 roads, signs and aerials on top of the mountains and a melting snowman
00:02:58:00 brass sundial
00:04:46:00 sign warning to ‘keep to the left of the poles’ and directional sign to ‘Hotham, Diamentina, Harrietville’
00:05:20:00 chair lift pulley station and 1970s style four wheel drive vehicle, a chalet and hamlet
00:05:55:00 a small A-frame chalet or hut
00:06:30:00 views of roads, trees and cars with the mountains in the background
00:07:05:00 two purple swamp hens (common to wetlands or rivers of Eastern Australia)
00:07:50:00 signs ‘Mount Buffalo’ and ‘Eurobin Falls’ followed by views of cascading waters over rocky embankments and cliffs
00:08:30:00 sign ‘Mackeys Lookout’ followed by views out over the valleys below including cars negotiating the tight turns on the roads winding down the mountain
00:09:08:00 sign ‘Rollarson’s Falls’
00:09:35:00 hikers negotiate logs and rocks along the path
00:10:16:00 a long narrow waterfall into a lovely natural rock pool
00:11:00:00 looking out over misty valleys through an old walk bridge
00:13:08:00 a narrow waterfall in a rocky cliffface
00:13:36:00 snow along the sides of the road
00:14:26:00 sign ‘Toownag Gap, Mt Buffalo, Mt Bogong’ and a visitor looking through binoculars from a lookout
00:14:46:00 looking down from a higher vantage spot on a long windy road through the mountains toward a township beyond
00:15:20:00 views of electricity towers across the ranges
00:15:50:00 sign ‘Pretty Valley Branch East Kiewa River’
00:16:11:00 sign ‘rocky Valley Dam’ and scenes around the dam
00:17:05:00 sign ‘Strawberry Saddle’ followed by a mob of emus
00:18:07:00 sign ‘Bundara River’ in the Victorian Alpine Region
00:19:50:00 sign ‘Omeo’, Victoria, followed by an older style cattle truck travelling along a street and the Public Telegraph Office in the township

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 17]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film shows a group of holiday makers camping on Phillip Island in Victoria. Wallace shows several good close-ups of the koalas that are a feature of the island and one of the old kilns of the chicory industry of the past that are dotted over the landscape. There are also views of the bridge that was built in 1969 between San Remo on the mainland and Newhaven to replace the old wooden one, and many views of rolling, crashing waves on rocky coastline.

Originally made on Super 8mm film, there is a gap of several seconds a few minutes in, beginning at 00:02:42:00 and ending at 00:02:58:00.

00:00:02:00 views of the sea from a high cliff top vantage point
00:00:39:00 hikers sitting on a cliff looking out over the sea
00:00:51:00 a grassy habitat hole for an animal, sand dunes, grasslands and cliffs looking out to sea
00:01:41:00 hikers gather around what might be a weather station
00:02:08:00 a large black snake moving over the grass
00:02:59:00 the bridge from San Remo to Newhaven on Phillip Island followed by fishing boats, yachts and various views of the bridge and surrounds
00:03:42:00 fishing boats and yachts, from a view under the bridge
00:03:56:00 the piers at San Remo
00:04:15:00 the rocky shallow foreshore and jettys at Newhaven
00:04:44:00 coastal grass blowing in the wind
00:05:38:00 a foreshore viewing platform, possibly at ‘The Nobbies’ on Phillip Island
00:06:40:00 a 1970s style car with surfboards on the roof racks and two young men standing by
00:07:40:00 views of rocky coastlines, crashing waves and rolling surf
00:08:59:00 people walking along a wooden walkway on the foreshore
00:10:18:00 two men ‘mutton-birding’ - seeking out Shearwater birds (previously called muttonbirds)
00:10:24:00 a Shearwater fledgling held up to the camera
00:10:51:00 a group of hikers or bird-watchers (some with binoculars) or general nature-lovers listening to a speaker who they then clap and then walking off
00:12:21:00 a close-up of a koala in a gumtree
00:12:29:00 hikers walking along a muddy track followed by a small rowing boat
00:12:57:00 a young man with a camera and another koala in a tree
00:13:11:00 slicing bacon off a large piece at a picnic table
00:13:25:00 a 1970s three legged barbeque
00:14:40:00 shooing flies from lunch plate
00:15:00:00 using binoculars to look out to sea, views of sand dunes and a ‘Land Rover’ vehicle with surfboard stacked on top having some difficulty driving over the sand dunes
00:15:49:00 a passenger rides on the bonnet of the ‘Land Rover’ as it traverses the dunes
00:16:45:00 a seagull on an old ‘No Standing’ sign
00:16:50:00 pitching a tent in long grass, a woman cleans her teeth over a bucket, a view of the campsite and a woman goes off with a shovel and toilet paper in old fashioned camp style
00:19:25:00 a group of horses
00:20:03:00 a small jetty and some boats including a yacht with a lovely red sail
00:20:28:00 1970s model ‘Holden’ station wagon vehicle lowering a boat into the water and a tractor carrying a boat to the water’s edge
00:21:56:00 one of the remaining chicory kilns on the island which would seem to have been converted to a pottery kiln (Phillip Island had a chicory growing industry until the 1960s)
00:22:50:00 caged birds of different varieties
00:24:23:00 a lone grave with ironwork surround and headstone reading ‘William Phillip Grossard’ (who died in a gunshot accident, 1868)
00:25:45:00 women swimming in ‘one piece’ bathing suits and swimming caps, walking along the beach and back to the campsite

The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film shows a group of holiday makers camping on Phillip Island in Victoria. Wallace shows several good close-ups of the koalas that are a feature of the island and one of the old kilns of the chicory industry of the past that are dotted over the landscape. There are also views of the bridge that was built in 1969 between San Remo on the mainland and Newhaven to replace the old wooden one, and many views of rolling, crashing waves on rocky coastline.

Originally made on Super 8mm film, there is a gap of several seconds a few minutes in, beginning at 00:02:42:00 and ending at 00:02:58:00.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 7]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film captures a group trip by tourist bus, four wheel drive vehicles and truck around the ‘Gulf Country’. The Gulf Country is the region of woodland and savanna grassland surrounding the Gulf of Carpentaria in north western Queensland and parts of the Northern Territory, Australia.

We see many dirt roads and sandy tracks so that we see both a tourist bus and four wheel drive vehicles being dug out of the sand. As always, Wallace includes close-ups of any flora and fauna that catch
his eye along the way.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Gulf Country’, ‘A WHC Film’
00:01:15:00 sign for ‘Four Wheel Drive’.
00:01:21:00 a large lorry style truck travelling ahead on dirt road.
00:01:31:00 digging a vehicle out of sand on a track.
00:02:30:00 tourist bus being hauled from the sandy track by a truck.
00:03:42:00 particularly colourful bird in a tree.
00:03:57:00 people in a small boat catching fish.
00:04:55:00 a row of tents for camping lined up along a riverbank.
00:07:45:00 close up of a blackened ‘billy can’ set over a fire and then a wider shot of a group of picnic-goers.
00:08:09:00 a woman in an example of a 1970s style ‘halter-neck’ top.
00:08:32:00 animal footprints in the dust followed by a large snake making progress through the grass
00:09:14:00 large truck and bus with baggage loaded on roof travel down a dusty road
00:09:57:00 cattle in stockyards
00:10:27:00 wetlands and wildflowers
00:11:45:00 swimming in a river
00:11:53:00 a close-up of a spider in the middle of a large web wit the blue of the river in the background
00:12:53:00 title card ‘The End’

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 28]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film captures a ‘Walkabouters’ trip to the Werribee National Park in Victoria. As well as the landscape, wildflowers and insects that Wallace always likes to film, there are scenes of the campsite, pitching tents and preparing food on open fires as well as gas campstoves. A visit to Blackwood Pottery is also included where Wallace shows the mesmerising process of pottery being made by hand at a pottery wheel.

Originally made on Super 8mm film. The film has a soundtrack of music and Wallace’s narration but the quality is not good. The sound drops out early in the film for several seconds and is a little hard to understand at times.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 titles ‘The Walkabouters’, ‘Werribee Gorge Nov 1972’
00:01:13:00 putting up camping tents
00:01:37:00 taking a break at a picnic table near a campfire, possibly drinking wine from wine flagons
00:01;53:00 cooking sausages on a barbeque iron plate over the open flames, sitting in 1970s style folding chairs
00:02:02:00 an old utility style truck with participants packed in the back as other participants set off walking
00:02:38:00 assisting each other as hikers are traversing a rocky creek and bending under the barbed wire of a farm fence while others hold wire up
00:03:51:00 using cameras and binoculars while listening to a guide or club member talking about the Gorge, followed by precarious crossing over water by using an old fallen tree
00:04:50:00 views around the landscape
00:06:05:00 hikers rest among the trees
00:08:10:00 views around the landscape and from a higher vantage point down to the river and tents
00:09:16:00 getting rock samples
00:09:50:00 views of the Werribee River and the rocky steep banks
00:10:15:00 views along the river, rocky outcrops and trickling waterfalls
00:11:09:00 preparing a meal back at base camp
00:12:12:00 eggs and bacon cooking on the open fire and a view of the tents
00:12:49:00 clambering over a farm gate
00:12:58:00 horses and cows
00:14:12:00 a colourful bug on a leaf
00:15:12:00 soaking tired feet in the creek
00:18:40:00 sign for ‘Blackwood Pottery’ followed by the pottery studio
00:19:15:00 views around the studio and potters at their wheels
00:20:15:00 the pottery kiln
00:21:31:00 an old cement camp fireplace barbeque with billies boiling and meat cooking
00:21:49:00 serving the billy tea at a park picnic table
00:22:08:00 eating the barbequed chops in bread, sleeping under a tree and photographing the scenery
00:23:53:00 close-ups of wildflowers
00:25:17:00 outdoor eating back at the tents
00:25:26:00 canoeing down the river
00:26:09:00 title ‘The End’

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 20]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film shows a trip to Papua New Guinea in 1961. The filmmaker captures a seaside town, fishing boats, people at a market and men in traditional headdresses, as well as the Boumana (Bomana) War Cemetery in Port Moresby.

Selected highlights list:
00:01:27:00 fishing boats by the sea
00:02:05:00 group of women sitting around talking
00:03:19:00 young child
00:04:21:00 boats in the bay
00:05:21:00 sign for ‘Boumana War Cemetery’
00:06:45:00 views across a valley
00:07:04:00 a waterfall
00:09:05:00 men in headdresses
00:09:16:00 a polo game with locals watching
00:10:57:00 views over the bay
00:12:44:00 girls playing a ball game
00:13:15:00 man fixing a small boat
00:14:00:00 a traffic warden in the middle of an intersection
00:15:16:00 views from an aeroplane

results.brief_description:

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 30]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

In this film, Wallace focuses on Australian birdlife, particularly waterbirds filmed from a small boat among lily pads and overhanging trees on still waterways located in the Northern Territory of Australia.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’ (dramatically placed over a crocodile with jaws raised and open), ‘Wild Paradise’
00:00:18:00 a close-up of bougainvillea, some men in shorts look nervously at the camera and cormorants (water birds) stand among water lilies and reeds
00:00:49:00 the men take to the water in a small fishing boat with outboard motor and pass by some waterbirds including cormorants, a large pelican, white egrets
00:02:01:00 the boat passes a flock of magpie geese followed by more pelicans, storks and black ibis
00:02:38:00 a white bellied sea eagle perched in a tree
00:02:48:00 some spoonbill and other water birds
00:04:05:00 a large black necked stork takes off in flight
00:04:13:00 a pelican stands with a chick close by
00:04:45:00 views around the river and wetlands
00:05:26:00 a lone magpie goose stands at the water and a few white egrets in flight
00:06:10:00 a darter water bird perched in a tree
00:06:23:00 an eagle on the very top of a tree
00:06:43:00 a large pelican sitting among lily pads
00:06:48:00 the sightseers on their boat
00:08:19:00 campsite alongside the river
00:09:44:00 water buffalo, dirt roads and flowering trees
00:10:50:00 irrigation in a banana tree plantation
00:11:09:00 a tourist bus on a dusty road
00:11:46:00 what appears to be an old ‘fan boat’ for skimming over swamps and wetlands
00:12:23:00 a black and white heron looking for dinner in the water
00:14:47:00 vehicles on a road leading into a town
00:15:11:00 driving into Darwin
00:15:49:00 the ‘Paspalis Centrepoint’ building in Darwin
00:15:54:00 a banner across the road for a concert featuring ‘Australian Crawl’ and ‘John Farnham’

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 5: Part 2]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is part two of two and is titled ‘Innes National Park’, and contains scenes from the Park, located in South Australia, including the rolling wavy sea viewed from rocky cliff tops of the park coastline, the dunes, wildflowers and beach tracks.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:04:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Innes National Park’, ‘A WHC Film’
00:00:55:00 campsite including an open fire with ‘billycan’, and a tarpaulin being set up as cover.
00:04:07:00 sign for ‘Innes National Park’
00:04:27:00 sign for ‘Shell Beach’
00:06:15:00 shifting sands in a dune.
00:08:04:00 sign for ‘The Gap’
00:08:51:00 ‘Inneston’ sign
00:10:36:00 ‘Stenhouse Bay’
